C025E70483D647E9AEF6A52E692110BC.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., demonstrate concern for self and others in planning and carrying out experimental activities involving the heating of materials; select safe methods for collecting evidence and solving problems)

11736FC83DE2433393AE91623BAC0720.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., recognize that human actions today may affect the sustainability of biomes for future generations; identify, without bias, potential conflicts between responding to human wants and needs and protecting the environment)

AC4CE0FE9EB349879E6F0BCE52A781F8.description: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., choose a variety of strategies, such as active listening, paraphrasing and questioning, in order to understand other points of view; consider a variety of perspectives and seek consensus before making decisions)

B85A314F78234317AFD333679C8D375C.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., view a situation from different perspectives, propose options and compare them when making decisions or taking action; evaluate inferences and conclusions with a critical mind and without bias, being cognizant of the many factors involved in experimentation)

B0BEEF7E3BCA431D9BCB0CF4DA0B40B5.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., appreciate Aboriginal clothing and home designs of the past and present that use locally-available materials to adapt to climate; recognize that science and technology develop in response to global concerns, as well as to local needs; consider more than one factor or perspective when making decisions on Science, Technology and Society [STS] issues)

2F49FDACED1E45908903DBA3B0E6C7C7.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., expand their inquiries beyond the classroom and into their everyday lives; show interest in careers related to climate and the environment)

62BB9E5D4CD7495CB598136283B9D257.description: develop, present and defend a position or course of action, based on findings (e.g., a strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions caused by the transportation of people and goods)

5A8E06EA185C4AA39D76E3A513C8A549.description: identify multiple perspectives that influence a science-related decision or issue (e.g., consult a wide variety of electronic sources that reflect varied viewpoints and economic, social, scientific and other perspectives on global warming and climate change)

792AD85C6296492EB76E172FD6C3A98B.description: synthesize information from multiple sources or from complex and lengthy texts, and make inferences based on this information (e.g., use integrated software effectively and efficiently to produce work that incorporates data, graphics and text)

8D463754D6D24EFC8E7885F2A2DD4607.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., use appropriate Système international (SI) units, fundamental and derived units, significant digits)

11C879C67FF24416920DDB72844B1B8D.description: represent large and small numbers using appropriate scientific notation

41BBA5FD0A604820A5240B0527F0FBBC.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work as members of a team in addressing problems, and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

EA66D3C78C744541BEDE65EABEA2127F.description: propose alternative solutions to a given practical problem, identify the potential strengths and weaknesses of each, and select one as the basis for a plan (e.g., design a home for a specific climate; analyze traditional Aboriginal home designs for their suitability in particular climates)

189F2A143A994ABAB31486294A640950.description: explain how data support or refute a hypothesis or a prediction (e.g., provide evidence for or against the hypothesis that human activity is responsible for climate change)

BA707F91064A45B4B2F314EDAAF1807D.description: state a conclusion based on experimental data, and explain how evidence gathered supports or refutes the initial hypothesis (e.g., summarize an analysis of the relationship between human activity and changing biomes)

7E3559E2899D4BB39C1B407F044825B6.description: identify limitations of data, evidence or measurement (e.g., list the limitations of data and evidence of past climate changes, evaluate the validity of interpolations and extrapolations, use significant digits appropriately)

8E94803B6B7947AF8251D36D92A6D168.description: interpret patterns and trends in data, and infer or calculate linear and nonlinear relationships among variables (e.g., analyze a graph of mean monthly temperatures for cities that are at similar latitudes but have different climates)

FF7A1012DF7842A69275D8AD8CB007B8.description: identify and apply criteria for evaluating evidence and sources of information, including identifying bias (e.g., investigate the issue of global climate change)

DDE138BA74964E1FB0312F6B8ECEA5FA.description: compile and display, by hand or computer, evidence and information in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., construct climate graphs to compare any two of the following biomes: grassland, desert, tundra, taiga, deciduous forest, rain forest)

F0DDFE66A2B045D18113E5983C442B8A.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

0E2DE1EE4FBA42D38A1C7628EC50A4AF.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., collect weather and climate data, both historic and current, from the Internet)

55FBDFFC011E4BE28DF3E3A0FADB2F48.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., research sources of greenhouse gases; research protocols to control human sources of greenhouse gases)

B06C4DF20C7642988FF1DEDC995AF2F5.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation of the data (e.g., organize data to prepare climatographs for comparing biomes)

C3354A26DA154A4C8F6B4B009E1AF406.description: use instruments, effectively and accurately, to collect data (e.g., use a barometer, rain gauge, thermometer, anemometer)

5D61E7A1FA5F461F94B1C7C824918DA8.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables and adapting or extending procedures where required (e.g., perform an experiment to determine the ability of various materials to absorb or reflect solar energy)

EAA4C9138A3E40FCB9BEB18D23F63346.description: Performing and Recording: Conduct investigations into relationships between and among observable variables, and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information

A61473751AA145FE8593D5C1AD174A75.description: formulate operational definitions of major variables (e.g., define heat of fusion or vaporization as the quantity of energy to change the state of one mole of matter at its melting or boiling point in the absence of temperature change)

5133B316E78946D5BDA6281B422E016C.description: design an experiment, and identify specific variables (e.g., investigate the heating effect of solar energy, using variables, such as temperature, efficiency and materials used)

EA06806D473D420F87243C90ED666F27.description: identify questions to investigate that arise from practical problems and issues (e.g., develop questions related to climate change, such as "How will global warming affect Canada's northern biomes?"; "How will a species be affected by an increase or decrease in average temperature?"

649ACA5A37ED45DFB0E28A9D241B5151.description: Initiating and Planning: Ask questions about observed relationships, and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues

87BBF1DCC7B84EF492DF9AC60438096D.description: assess, from a variety of perspectives, the risks and benefits of human activity, and its impact on the biosphere and the climate (e.g., compare the Gaia hypothesis with traditional Aboriginal perspectives on the natural world; identify and analyze various perspectives on reducing the impact of human activity on the global climate)

3DE740A6A6AB41818AA6F102F7C01D5D.description: describe the limitations of scientific knowledge and technology in making predictions related to climate and weather (e.g., predicting the direct and indirect impacts on Canada's agriculture, forestry and oceans of climate change, or from changes in energy transfer systems, such as ocean currents and global wind patterns)

E645DD15F60C43EDBE60AAC9F16860FD.description: describe the role of technology in measuring, modelling and interpreting climate and climate change (e.g., computer models, devices to take measurements of greenhouse gases, satellite imaging technology)

F61D0EC97651467D88D90B360DD3551E.description: describe and evaluate the role of science in furthering the understanding of climate and climate change through international programs (e.g., World Meteorological Organization, World Weather Watch, Global Atmosphere Watch, Surface Heat Budget of the Arctic Ocean (SHEBA) project, The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC); the study of paleoclimates and models of future climate scenarios)

3A3F649FC739406FAECCAE1C8028B236.description: identify evidence to investigate past changes in Earth's climate (e.g., ice core samples, tree ring analysis)

E4CD5A49192D4455BF50174D685D53C5.description: investigate and identify human actions affecting biomes that have a potential to change climate (e.g., emission of greenhouse gases, draining of wetlands, forest fires, deforestation) and critically examine the evidence that these factors play a role in climate change (e.g., global warming, rising sea level(s))

C2743422E3E547C4A5862348E30F4BB9.description: Investigate and interpret the role of environmental factors on global energy transfer and climate change

207C26EEAED6477AB6CBD9261AB34605.description: identify the potential effects of climate change on environmentally sensitive biomes (e.g., impact of a reduction in the Arctic ice pack on local species and on Aboriginal societies that rely on traditional lifestyles)

C80646ABCA844F0FB7D31F471FD220DD.description: analyze the climatographs of two major biomes (i.e., grasslands, desert, tundra, taiga, deciduous and rain forest) and explain why biomes with similar characteristics can exist in different geographical locations, latitudes and altitudes

397A4BE57BD2419DB28C2F3715B16FD7.description: relate the characteristics of two major biomes (i.e., grassland, desert, tundra, taiga, deciduous and rain forest) to net radiant energy, climatic factors (temperature, moisture, sunlight and wind) and topography (mountain ranges, large bodies of water)

ED9AA4A2C49C457C8171122162F76C5E.description: describe a biome as an open system in terms of input and output of energy and matter and exchanges at its boundaries (e.g., compare and contrast cells and biomes as open systems)

7BB53948D3BC49A5A329CE902262A34E.description: Relate climate to the characteristics of the world's major biomes, and compare biomes in different regions of the world

5AC553FF683342C68D26ECC7F805E6E5.description: nvestigate and explain how evaporation, condensation, freezing and melting transfer thermal energy; i.e., use simple calculations of heat of fusion and vaporization  , and Q=mcΔt to convey amounts of thermal energy involved, and link these processes to the hydrologic cycle.

EF79B11AF42A4096BF406D9F1583FC74.description: investigate and interpret how variations in thermal properties of materials can lead to uneven heating and cooling

665C69668ABA43DAB359286CA9CC4C2A.description: explain how thermal energy transfer through the atmosphere and hydrosphere affects climate

5140CE76DAB6404E8B59408785841017.description: investigate and describe, in general terms, the relationships among solar energy reaching Earth's surface and time of year, angle of inclination, length of daylight, cloud cover, albedo effect and aerosol or particulate distribution

A21655C2F47047A7A184463F0B411032.description: describe, in general terms, how thermal energy is transferred through the atmosphere (i.e., global wind patterns, jet stream, Coriolis effect, weather systems) and through the hydrosphere (i.e., ocean currents, large bodies of water) from latitudes of net radiation surplus to latitudes of net radiation deficit, resulting in a variety of climatic zones (e.g., analyze static and animated satellite images)

A7C5E3C32C8C425DA964D51E7E09DBBA.description: Analyze the relationships among net solar energy, global energy transfer processes - primarily radiation, convection and hydrologic cycle - and climate.

19BE703E0B9C4AA09F5CB10E6304F2C9.description: describe and explain the greenhouse effect, and the role of various gases - including methane, carbon dioxide and water vapour - in determining the scope of the greenhouse effect

F1A3CD178023464EB6C16D1471BC8636.description: describe the major characteristics of the atmosphere, the hydrosphere and the lithosphere, and explain their relationship to Earth's biosphere

1F175883DFFC46C0844211AA278B3D51.description: analyze, in general terms, the net radiation budget, using per cent; i.e., solar energy input, terrestrial energy output, net radiant energy

1FEAE75A104A4DF2B91B88737D54A479.description: identify the Sun as the source of all energy on Earth

32EF7E83CB77401A8C729B08FDA6ED6F.description: explain how climate affects the lives of people and other species, and explain the need to investigate climate change (e.g., describe the responses of human and other species to extreme climatic conditions; describe housing designs, animal habitats, clothing and fur in conditions of extreme heat, cold, dryness or humidity, wind)

9BCDF774D08F46AD9CDE40E3AA7FE40B.description: Describe how the relationships among input solar energy, output terrestrial energy and energy flow within the biosphere affect the lives of humans and other species

C3EFC796435341FD826A039821B39574.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

3D1BBC24B3CB459284E84A1D79365111.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., demonstrate concern for self and others in planning and carrying out experimental activities; select safe methods of collecting evidence and solving problems)

5DFE78D198E74676864AA86F9F57BB3C.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., show care and respect for all forms of life; evaluate the impact on the environment of personal choices, as well as the choices scientists make when carrying out an investigation)

AE1AAFBBADBD42ADB6A2CB1F2F7A9BAD.description: Work collaboratively in planning and carrying out investigations, as well as in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., assume responsibility for their share of the work in preparing for investigations, gathering and recording data; consider alternative approaches suggested by group members)

4B0914D54FA14B739FCE00DDFC50E375.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., recognize that traditional Aboriginal cultures employed the principles of scientific inquiry through observation and experimentation to solve a variety of unique challenges)

1BA882CB67894A95874732C455948462.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., value the roles and contributions of men and women from many cultures in using science and technology to further our understanding of the cell and of living systems, recognize and appreciate the contributions of the traditional knowledge of Aboriginal peoples to science and technology)

B43152D85BB84889A5D05147A8942EBF.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., apply concepts learned in the classroom to everyday phenomena related to cells and multicellular organisms; investigate careers in fields, such as botany, forestry, horticulture, cytology, genetics and health care)

6B0D466349504D3F969573332EB31A69.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., draw analogies between division of labour in cells and in communities; record and explain the movement of water in plants)

ED0C2649C13044E38ABFFE801CADF6A2.description: communicate questions, ideas and intentions; and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others (e.g., describe cytoplasmic streaming in a single-celled organism, and communicate an inference about similar movement in the cells of a multicellular organism)

644AFA5E90CA4D8C8570F06759B86614.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work as members of a team in addressing problems, and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

3293DD43B9CD48AA8566A3892ECA6F22.description: identify new questions or problems that arise from what was learned (e.g., determine the purpose of cellular structures from observations of fresh and prepared materials, using dissecting and compound microscopes, or micrographs)

C6183B14F17D48E7BF55BC9362A5209D.description: construct and test a prototype of a device or system, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., create a model of a cell to illustrate a certain function, for example, use a balloon and tape to represent a guard cell)

ACF7E333308C497EA0FD95372981B7AE.description: explain how data support or refute a hypothesis or prediction

49870A944A864009A7D9E83ABA1B05A2.description: state a conclusion based on experimental data, and explain how evidence gathered supports or refutes the initial hypothesis (e.g., observe and record macroscopic and microscopic changes in a growing plant for evidence of differentiation)

E33C34E4AD3E433FA6DFCF1209E666FF.description: interpret patterns and trends in data, and infer or calculate linear and nonlinear relationships among variables (e.g., compare the surface area to volume ratio of various cells, and relate the findings to the function of each cell; trace ingredients in modern medicines to their traditional counterparts)

1F36FFFFEA364BCBBC0FAD4DB44FA562.description: compile and display, by hand or computer, evidence and information in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., collect data on the number of stomata per unit area on various plant leaves that grow in areas of differing humidity, and compile this data in a spreadsheet and graph it to determine whether there is a relationship between the variables)

28644C6F657D458C89E85565B7191FB0.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

80ADF0D07AB94E9883E81781FC286A33.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., create electronic documents containing multiple links, or summarize articles based on the scientific principles and/or technological developments)

1E46E2A4A4E24F5DA07D7ED99998D0EA.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., upload and download text, image, audio and video files on emerging technologies for studying cells)

BDC602E412444785A0E172BC77CAEF7A.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation of the data (e.g., organize data obtained from measuring daily temperature and bloom dates of plant species, such as aspen, poplar, common purple lilac and crocus to determine a relationship between the two variables)

0203EDD2FF0940F59FBE1C705EA306BC.description: estimate quantities (e.g., compare sizes of various types of cells under the microscope; calculate magnification, field of view and scale)

DCE603EB6AED4C119969AB0A232D6528.description: use instruments effectively and accurately for collecting data (e.g., use a microscope to observe movement of water in plants; prepare wet mounts of tissue from flowering plants, and observe cellular structures specific to plant and animal cells; stain cells to make them visible)

1ED9500151914856A81B008166A4806E.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables and adapting or extending procedures (e.g., perform an experiment to determine the effect of tonicity on plasmolysis and deplasmolysis in plant cells, such as staminal hairs or aquatic leaf cells, identify variables that do affect plasmolysis, such as the amount of light and heat, and control these variables)

8CE7472A6E0B4139B77AB324280EC379.description: Performing and Recording: Conduct investigations into relationships between and among observable variables, and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information

03B4E2C973E045419372F7EFB5CC8C4D.description: formulate operational definitions of major variables (e.g., define concentration gradient, equilibrium)

95310583F975449E84C6AE616170D031.description: identify the theoretical basis of an investigation, and develop a prediction and a hypothesis that are consistent with the theoretical basis (e.g., use the particle theory to hypothesize how the rate of diffusion is affected by varying particle size, and then predict the rates of diffusion of a sucrose solution and a starch solution when placed into dialysis tubing in a beaker of water)

B262E5A2B85143AFB307904D85CEA379.description: state a prediction and a hypothesis based on available evidence and background information (e.g., hypothesize how biochemical interconversions of starch and glucose might regulate the turgor pressure of cells; hypothesize the direction of root and plant growth of a bean plant growing on a rotating turntable, and predict the effects of varying RPMs on the angle of growth)

43F2801B067E4BA78AECB2DAD145BB50.description: design an experiment, identifying and controlling major variables (e.g., design an investigation to determine the effect of CO2(g) concentration on the number of chloroplasts found in an aquatic plant cell)

A15717AECF7D44DF8AB19CFE287FF9DA.description: define and delimit problems to facilitate investigation (e.g., how do plants adjust to accommodate different environmental conditions such as varying levels of light and fertilizer)

94407396D7F54F8C9E1EB826B2798CCB.description: Initiating and Planning:Ask questions about observed relationships, and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues

997EBDDBA720466C81F3FA0130C5FE88.description: trace the development of theories of phototropism and gravitropism (e.g., from Darwin and Boysen-Jensen to Went)

05EDB5ACCBEF4018837B741ECE4C3744.description: explain and investigate phototropism and gravitropism as examples of control systems in plants

3FF7D37930FB4C8EAF80905F786A9A90.description: explain and investigate the gas exchange system in plants; i.e., lenticels, guard cells, stomata and the process of diffusion

FD2FADBD02AB4B39B28F9DB2D11C39DC.description: explain and investigate the transport system in plants; i.e., xylem and phloem tissues and the processes of transpiration, including the cohesion and adhesion properties of water, turgor pressure and osmosis; diffusion, active transport and root pressure in root hairs

E4C0CE4845B3459D98FCA20DE3AB0C06.description: describe how the cells of the leaf system have a variety of specialized structures and functions; i.e., epidermis including guard cells, palisade tissue cells, spongy tissue cells, and phloem and xylem vascular tissue cells to support the process of photosynthesis

592BC791F02D4230B1A607A985B0B673.description: explain why, when a single-celled organism or colony of single-celled organisms reaches a certain size, it requires a multicellular level of organization, and relate this to the specialization of cells, tissues and systems in plants

567527A8B9584BAFB328783C699B8F06.description: Analyze plants as an example of a multicellular organism with specialized structures at the cellular, tissue and system levels

D3B60567401941279682A1F0C429F2F7.description: describe cell size and shape as they relate to surface area to volume ratio, and explain how that ratio limits cell size (e.g., compare nerve cells and blood cells in animals, or plant root hair cells and chloroplast-containing cells on the surface of leaves)

AB6834008528446B933217D561EFDAC3.description: describe how knowledge about semi-permeable membranes, diffusion and osmosis is applied in various contexts(e.g., attachment of HIV drugs to cells and liposomes, diffusion of protein hormones into cells, staining of cells, desalination of sea water, peritoneal or mechanical dialysis, separation of bacteria from viruses, purification of water, cheese making, use of honey as an antibacterial agent and berries as a preservative agent by traditional First Nations communities)

C96385B31F334224B7E365F1A7B94CF2.description: describe the role of the cell membrane in maintaining equilibrium while exchanging matter

5E48728863474DE196A861237DEEC608.description: compare the structure, chemical composition and function of plant and animal cells, and describe the complementary nature of the structure and function of plant and animal cells

AFB0AABA32434464A6450CCB292D96AA.description: identify the structure and describe, in general terms, the function of the cell membrane, nucleus, lysosome, vacuole, mitochondrion, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, ribosomes, chloroplast and cell wall, where present, of plant and animal cells

62E322501FFE4AFABD61217673829C67.description: describe the cell as a functioning open system that acquires nutrients, excretes waste, and exchanges matter and energy

00E61579713C457096C81867033A2248.description: use models to explain and visualize complex processes like diffusion and osmosis, endo- and exocytosis, and the role of cell membrane in these processes

137DE745BC634EA291387D674A5E032B.description: compare passive transport of matter by diffusion and osmosis with active transport in terms of the particle model of matter, concentration gradients, equilibrium and protein carrier molecules(e.g., particle model of matter and fluid-mosaic model)

BF7DF18179E44FD0A5B534E0E6E22340.description: Describe the function of cell organelles and structures in a cell, in terms of life processes, and use models to explain these processes and their applications

C2E29C138DFA4A138B1DCB3FC1274B20.description: identify areas of cell research at the molecular level (e.g., DNA and gene mapping, transport across cell membranes)

B48FBC2F390D45D8BFCA0B14BF119827.description: describe how advancements in knowledge of cell structure and function have been enhanced and are increasing as a direct result of developments in microscope technology and staining techniques (e.g., electron microscope, confocal laser scanning microscope [CLSM])

E54A3B9BF51846EF9E70C8C018031F7E.description: trace the development of the cell theory: all living things are made up of one or more cells and the materials produced by these, cells are functional units of life, and all cells come from pre-existing cells (e.g., from Aristotle to Hooke, Pasteur, Brown, and Schwann and Schleiden; recognize that there are sub-cellular particles, such as viruses and prions, which have some characteristics of living cells)

16273312861E4884AF975C7DDA175988.description: Explain the relationship between developments in imaging technology and the current understanding of the cell

5A700CC652EF4AD090F2AB181BDEAE77.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

7085C5EFD46B4605978EE9701198DD0F.description: Cycling of Matter in Living Systems

DED70FC7D4334817BAE0FF4BCACDF9AF.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., demonstrate concern for self and others in planning and carrying out experimental activities and the design of devices; select safe methods for collecting evidence and solving problems)

ED5CBC6E9533413EB4BB4BA9C88DA9D6.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., recognize that their choices and actions, and the choices and actions that technologists make, can have an impact on others and on the environment)

280E5CF722804FE0B3742452399F1973.description: Work collaboratively in carrying out investigations and in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., select a variety of strategies, such as group brainstorming, active listening, paraphrasing and questioning, to find the best possible solution to a problem; work as a team member when assigning and performing tasks; accept responsibility for problems that arise)

6C02330F626345C58815F1C3434B6177.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., assess problem using a variety of criteria; respect alternative solutions; honestly evaluate limitations of their designs; be persistent in finding the best possible answer or solution to a question or problem)

B7872A0B6228425AB3AAAFADE08E2D37.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., appreciate Aboriginal technologies of the past and present that use locally-available materials and apply scientific principles; recognize that science and technology develop in response to global concerns, as well as to local needs)

330DFB1D02F24DBC8C4E98D9B7797D16.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., apply concepts learned in the classroom to everyday phenomena related to energy; show interest in a broad scope of science-related fields in which energy plays a significant role)

7322A8F1DB084A0FBE72993F0849BBBB.description: work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan and to troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., develop a plan to build an energy conversion device, seek feedback, test and review the plan, make revisions, and implement the plan)

082DED5F88C24BF285AC1CF769572413.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., use appropriate Système international (SI) units, fundamental and derived units; use advanced menu features within a word processor to accomplish a task and to insert tables, graphs, text and graphics)

B8FA7B86A59F47318C4CD6394C058B45.description: represent large and small numbers using appropriate scientific notation

3CD8805E69B5470C80443A8859E81935.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work as members of a team in addressing problems, and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

7D65E93208A94EAD8443EE87C56DFFA6.description: evaluate a personally designed and constructed device on the basis of self-developed criteria (e.g., evaluate an energy conversion device based on a modern or traditional design)

521348B0CE9844229E6F6F250B6816F6.description: propose alternative solutions to a given practical problem, identify the potential strengths and weaknesses of each and select one as the basis for a plan (e.g., assess whether coal or natural gas should be used to fuel thermal power plants in Alberta)

0604C8F5BC0F4BC5BFDC23B51E1B4755.description: construct and test a prototype of a device or system, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., design and build an energy conversion device)

3570B98F616F4A2C89BD67624740818D.description: state a conclusion based on experimental data, and explain how evidence gathered supports or refutes the initial hypothesis (e.g., explain the discrepancy between the theoretical and actual efficiency of a thermal energy conversion system)

DA3251D223CB474892334DDCB202B87F.description: compare theoretical and empirical values and account for discrepancies (e.g., determine the efficiency of thermal energy conversion systems)

D47DFDD11BA046F58F6B6FBABDF5FAEE.description: interpret patterns and trends in data, and infer or calculate linear and nonlinear relationships among variables (e.g., interpret a graph of changing kinetic and potential energy from a pendulum during one-half of a period of oscillation; calculate the slope of the line in a distance - time graph; analyze a simple velocity - time graph to describe acceleration; calculate the area under the line in a force - distance graph)

99965352DB6F43219A8B61907F3F305D.description: identify limitations of data or measurement (e.g., recognize that the measure of the local value of gravity varies globally; use significant digits appropriately)

E9E3CBDF92704501B30A6E4285CA6ECD.description: compile and display evidence and information, by hand or using technology, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., plot distance - time, velocity - time and force - distance graphs; manipulate and present data through the selection of appropriate tools, such as scientific instrumentation, calculators, databases or spreadsheets)

48C5FB8B994243FDAA829B598197D79C.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

77045F89C08444F79FB4B0EFB59A9B49.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., create electronic documents, containing multiple links, on using alternative energy sources, such as wind or solar, to generate electricity in Alberta; relate the importance of the development of effective and efficient engines to the time of the Industrial Revolution and to present-day first-world economics)

05E8731B99314B3F98E4A98F9F4F2CB7.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., compile information on the energy content of fuels used in Alberta power plants; trace the flow of energy from the Sun to the lighting system in the school, identifying what changes are taking place at each stage of the process)

05C49411A0D64AD98AD613D25ADFD4D1.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation of the data (e.g., use a computer-based laboratory to compile and organize data from an experiment to demonstrate the equivalency of work done on an object and the resulting kinetic energy)

01C854CCE03644AD9DBA7FF19AB2B585.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables and adapting or extending procedures (e.g., perform an experiment to demonstrate the equivalency of work done on an object and the resulting kinetic energy; design a device that converts mechanical energy into thermal energy)

3452E6B2481B4C168FB3F39177980441.description: Performing and Recording: Conduct investigations into relationships between and among observable variables, and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information

988098A8033145A4B96E0F04CCEFA37C.description: formulate operational definitions of major variables (e.g., predict or hypothesize the conversion of energy from potential form to kinetic form, in an experiment using a pendulum or free fall)

C6019562B39D42029593999070262FB0.description: design an experiment, identifying and controlling major variables (e.g., design an experiment involving a combustion reaction to demonstrate the conversion of chemical potential energy to thermal energy)

F7AC5F4EE041445ABEFE112C927D1792.description: Initiating and Planning: Ask questions about observed relationships, and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues

A898B393D1534B13B958D27836DB269C.description: explain the need for efficient energy conversions to protect our environment and to make judicious use of natural resources (e.g., advancement in energy efficiency; Aboriginal perspectives on taking care of natural resources)

13F7251987824C65B2C3C17DFC73EBFA.description: compare the energy content of fuels used in thermal power plants in Alberta, in terms of costs, benefits, efficiency and sustainability

E553204A10AE42E89213C3C5E6DFB3EE.description: apply concepts related to efficiency of thermal energy conversion to analyze the design of a thermal device (e.g., heat pump, high efficiency furnace, automobile engine)

FBFA017FA7A94DD188C2371D37168D8D.description: explain, quantitatively, efficiency as a measure of the "useful" work compared to the total energy put into an energy conversion process or device

5606C13E650A4E04B230C26EB2D2CAD2.description: recognize that there are limits to the amount of "useful" energy that can be derived from the conversion of potential energy to other forms in a technological device (e.g., when the potential energy of gasoline is converted to kinetic energy in an automobile engine, some is also converted to heat; when electrical energy is converted to light energy in a light bulb, some is also converted to heat)

64BC1177EB8947B6AF75DFC7AC96B5CD.description: define, operationally, "useful" energy from a technological perspective, and analyze the stages of "useful" energy transformations in technological systems (e.g., hydroelectric dam)

A8E0035FBD10435D9EC9496CE3F13FD4.description: describe how the first and second laws of thermodynamics have changed our understanding of energy conversions (e.g., why heat engines are not 100% efficient)

F3B106D41DE5438AA35FBC3531FF5DCE.description: describe, qualitatively and in terms of thermodynamic laws, the energy transformations occurring in devices and systems (e.g., automobile, bicycle coming to a stop, thermal power plant, food chain, refrigerator, heat pump, permafrost storage pits for food)

5ACB28A7951145759D896D5467E400A7.description: Apply the principles of energy conservation and thermodynamics to investigate, describe and predict efficiency of energy transformation in technological systems

07D48341790A49A6AF83E91910E2686A.description: investigate and analyze one-dimensional scalar motion and work done on an object or system, using algebraic and graphical techniques (e.g., the relationships among distance, time and velocity; determining the area under the line in a force - distance graph)

4D70D023FB614CA9896BBCA07763B856.description: derive the SI unit of energy and work, the joule, from fundamental units

53406A2E4D204184A28AB5DB50A428BF.description: quantify kinetic energy using Ek = 1/2 mv2 and relate this concept to energy conservation in transformations (e.g., for an object falling a distance "h" from rest: mgh = Fd = 1/2 mv2)

B985C943912E4A00941146729A6119EC.description: relate gravitational potential energy to work done using Ep= mgh and W = Fd and show that a change in energy is equal to work done on a system: ΔE = W

29FA6673B86A4DE389B90A4FAC48C593.description: define gravitational potential energy as the work against gravity

C0445C53A39F4362A806E8DAF1790251.description: recall, from previous studies, the operational definition for force as a push or a pull, and for work as energy expended when the speed of an object is increased, or when an object is moved against the influence of an opposing force

211A3068CED34453AE74F399B9AC031D.description: explain that, in the absence of resistive forces, motion at constant speed requires no energy input

B79253599D294405AA3365E226184666.description:
define acceleration, quantitatively, as a change in velocity during a time interval: →
a=∆→v/∆t

46E9BC2C758D4B6FBD451C706C7392B1.description: define, compare and contrast scalar and vector quantities

C9067F0883C74A528CF9757AD270F5D9.description: describe chemical energy as a form of potential energy (e.g., energy stored in glucose, adenosine triphosphate [ATP], gasoline)

36AF9042EAE349489F170D35D720DE91.description: define kinetic energy as energy due to motion, and define potential energy as energy due to relative position or condition

02505EC4F3BA4D4BB92805DB36D5F1D2.description: describe evidence for the presence of energy; i.e., observable physical and chemical changes, and changes in motion, shape or temperature

E2A02C9D262F4461B69B216270D8D128.description: Explain and apply concepts used in theoretical and practical measures of energy in mechanical systems

94DD01D6F9CB4C1ABD75F701166E48B8.description: analyze and illustrate how the concept of energy developed from observation of heat and mechanical devices (e.g., the investigations of Rumford and Joule; the development of pre-contact First Nations and Inuit technologies based on an understanding of thermal energy and transfer)

B31D067DFDF146E28366FA5DE98E9AF5.description: identify the processes of trial and error that led to the invention of the engine, and relate the principles of thermodynamics to the development of more efficient engine designs (e.g., the work of James Watt; improved valve designs in car engines)

4190645C401744E5ABB4E3299CF518C7.description: describe, qualitatively, current and past technologies used to transform energy from one form to another, and that energy transfer technologies produce measurable changes in motion, shape or temperature (e.g., hydroelectric and coal-burning generators, solar heating panels, windmills, fuel cells; describe examples of Aboriginal applications of thermodynamics in tool making, design of structures and heating)

F541F2B899CB483FA1CA9550493CF233.description: illustrate, by use of examples from natural and technological systems, that energy exists in a variety of forms (e.g., mechanical, chemical, thermal, nuclear, solar)

BF99AB42880D498692DF030C58E27D71.description: Analyze and illustrate how technologies based on thermodynamic principles were developed before the laws of thermodynamics were formulated

22DC292A94F041239E008829DCA63E90.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

800F54C5156B41D592B25EECF2893CE8.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., acknowledge the need for regulations to govern the storage, handling and disposal of potentially hazardous materials in the school laboratory and at home or in the workplace)

961599744DF1474BB8B3624A37931FBB.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., recognize that environmental consequences may arise from the development, use and disposal of chemical materials)

C2D274F128884BEA81EE1BA7E5397B20.description: Work collaboratively in planning and carrying out investigations, as well as in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., contribute to group work willingly, assume a variety of roles and accept responsibility for any problems that arise)

FE65A9911FFF4A439C6C880FEC29BF73.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., evaluate inferences and conclusions based on particles of matter that cannot be observed directly)

42E52B425529413EB28276375C37FB05.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., recognize the contributions of Canadians to contemporary knowledge of the structure of matter; show awareness of and respect for traditional Aboriginal knowledge about the use of biotic and abiotic materials)

B3264985FE7D4DC88AFBE02079D38AED.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., apply concepts learned in the classroom to the everyday use of chemicals; show interest in a broad scope of chemistry-related careers)

033120DFCC27433589617328A4D45D04.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., use appropriate Système international (SI) units, and IUPAC nomenclature)

D587CDD1AEC94999986873E4934C9934.description: represent large and small numbers using appropriate scientific notation

967DCEB75C43413FAB4507F8BD3928A0.description: communicate questions, ideas and intentions; and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others (e.g., use appropriate communication technology to elicit feedback from others)

687408533AED4DA7BE327B583B986EF8.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work as members of a team in addressing problems, and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

D8E021F803364609A88E0DD1D34BB963.description: identify new questions or problems that arise from what was learned (e.g., how did ancient peoples discover how to separate metals from their ores?; evaluate the traditional Aboriginal method for determining alkaline properties of substances)

D7707DC0C1214CA4BEBDE6F730E09E4F.description: identify and explain sources of error and uncertainty in measurement, and express results in a form that acknowledges the degree of uncertainty (e.g., measure and record the mass of a material, use significant digits appropriately)

535C18A19EF14491A154D1B39B23ED16.description: compare theoretical and empirical values and account for discrepancies (e.g., measure the mass of a chemical reaction system before and after a change, and account for any discrepancies)

1A6CA84B33A542548235B814A6F5AB21.description: apply and assess alternative theoretical models for interpreting knowledge in a given field (e.g., compare models for the structure of the atom)

867F6AC208C24E939045AA8FABF5EA2C.description: describe and apply classification systems and nomenclature used in the sciences (e.g., investigate periodicity in the periodic table, classify matter, and name elements and compounds based on IUPAC guidelines)

16A094F5F1A4470CA36D2547D8CB150E.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions

4AED8D7ACE48483CB3070D9AE0A08D01.description: select and use apparatus, technology and materials safely (e.g., use equipment, such as Bunsen burners, electronic balances, laboratory glassware, electronic probes and calculators correctly and safely)

024ECC42DA284326A3D74882DE92912E.description: demonstrate a knowledge of WHMIS standards by selecting and applying proper techniques for the handling and disposal of laboratory materials (e.g., recognize and use Material Safety Data Sheets [MSDS] information)

08659C8AFD8A48E5B34670E392127727.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., collect information on research into subatomic matter, research how pre-contact First Nations communities used available materials such as brain tissue for tanning hides)

BDF61B155F9541D89934AF3B784A5814.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., information on compounds we use and their toxicity, using standard references, such as the Merck Index, as well as Internet searches)

D1EAB93E4BA643B298895EDE59A4568C.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables and adapting or extending procedures (e.g., when performing an experiment to illustrate conservation of mass, demonstrate an understanding of closed and open systems and control for loss or gain of matter during a chemical change)

5817EE3750FF434FB41DF9050B87D65E.description: Performing and Recording: Conduct investigations into relationships between and among observable variables, and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information

508680255A7746509A7FEF36B5F10B07.description: evaluate and select appropriate instruments for collecting evidence and appropriate processes for problem solving, inquiring and decision making (e.g., list appropriate technology for classifying compounds, such as litmus paper or conductivity tester)

20D41D52BF534321B316659DE465A143.description: state a prediction and a hypothesis based on available evidence and background information (e.g., state a hypothesis about what happens to baking soda during baking)

C72F61F431934D77A4C258691DEC609C.description: design an experiment, identifying and controlling major variables (e.g., design an experiment to differentiate between categories of matter, such as acids, bases and neutral solutions, and identify manipulated and responding variables)

E9FE198C8FA54B9690161D12DB82FBBF.description: define and delimit problems to facilitate investigation

73EAD457AA114838931DD2490D0E79F9.description: Initiating and Planning: Ask questions about observed relationships, and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues:

37541A87C3B040CDBB847F0BB14A010D.description: interpret balanced chemical equations in terms of moles of chemical species, and relate the mole concept to the law of conservation of mass

BF518A19B08F4A32AEBC3616EE78B452.description: define the mole as the amount of an element containing 6.02 x 1023 atoms (Avogadro's number) and apply the concept to calculate quantities of substances made of other chemical species (e.g., determine the quantity of water that contains 6.02 x1023 molecules of H2O)

8A8367B84E174ACBA2A3E1D186FAD873.description: predict the products of formation (synthesis) and decomposition, single and double replacement, and hydrocarbon combustion chemical reactions, when given the reactants

2DB8349880C6490D9CF26C6EAED42D76.description: translate word equations to balanced chemical equations and vice versa for chemical reactions that occur in living and nonliving systems

18FEA12C08E04BD5A36A46BC8B509DFB.description: classify and identify categories of chemical reactions; i.e., formation (synthesis), decomposition, hydrocarbon combustion, single replacement, double replacement

695F0AE0FB7443A4B2503584B445931D.description: differentiate between endothermic and exothermic chemical reactions (e.g., combustion of gasoline and other natural and synthetic fuels, photosynthesis)

B1C7C6416B0540EAB43E1739FC74EB14.description: describe the evidence for chemical changes; i.e., energy change, formation of a gas or precipitate, colour or odour change, change in temperature

71CF7627824344ED9031C68C60CF3F11.description: identify chemical reactions that are significant in societies (e.g., reactions that maintain living systems, such as photosynthesis and respiration; reactions that have an impact on the environment, such as combustion reactions and decomposition of waste materials)

DFE1A7BF6A6E489F80A9BAD7D2EFECCC.description: provide examples of household, commercial and industrial processes that use chemical reactions to produce useful substances and energy (e.g., baking powder in baking, combustion of fuels, electrolysis of water into H2(g) and O2(g))

370BC3D7E5164C6998CCC8F982BA1A8E.description: Identify and classify chemical changes, and write word and balanced chemical equations for significant chemical reactions, as applications of Lavoisier's law of conservation of mass

A16FCFB1DE2F408E9872310757D545B8.description: outline the issues related to personal and societal use of potentially toxic or hazardous compounds (e.g., health hazards due to excessive consumption of alcohol and nicotine; exposure to toxic substances; environmental concerns related to the handling, storage and disposal of heavy metals, strong acids, flammable gases, volatile liquids)

078C04BC91FD43C8B4DEF3D697F93354.description: relate the molecular structure of simple substances to their properties (e.g., describe how the properties of water are due to the polar nature of water molecules, and relate this property to the transfer of energy in physical and living systems)

91A3AD13FAFC4D32B57AE777606FD2D3.description: predict whether an ionic compound is relatively soluble in water, using a solubility chart

04407E34E3964BA48F6E1012A0814066.description: classify ionic and molecular compounds, acids and bases on the basis of their properties; i.e., conductivity, pH, solubility, state

C829FAC5DFD246CFBE2C56BF4589E805.description: predict formulas and write names for ionic and molecular compounds and common acids (e.g., sulfuric, hydrochloric, nitric, ethanoic), using a periodic table, a table of ions and IUPAC rules

6DA4B8E32E044345B3D899E98948935F.description: explain, using the periodic table, how and why elements combine to form compounds in specific ratios

11B9439574E94DF697C57FE68AC0BB99.description: explain the importance of and need for the IUPAC system of naming compounds, in terms of the work that scientists do and the need to communicate clearly and precisely

29F958C8FB8C418CB81D5A20FED0DC2C.description: illustrate an awareness of WHMIS guidelines, and demonstrate safe practices in the handling, storage and disposal of chemicals in the laboratory and at home

4A8A9795A5584BB3AFA2BBB2816B43AC.description: Explain, using the periodic table, how elements combine to form compounds, and follow IUPAC guidelines for naming ionic compounds and simple molecular compounds

40F5B6159B5245F78DF2A7529CB6762D.description: identify examples of chemistry-based careers in the community (e.g., chemical engineering, cosmetology, food processing)

7DACD97C329941089991EB6F97174873.description: outline the role of evidence in the development of the atomic model consisting of protons and neutrons (nucleons) and electrons; i.e., Dalton, Thomson, Rutherford, Bohr

8813BC130C1C4F2991946AAF47BF87ED.description: identify historical examples of how humans worked with chemical substances to meet their basic needs (e.g., how pre-contact First Nations communities used biotic and abiotic materials to meet their needs)

76F679C7DF464F2F9625C2C8CC703EE1.description: Describe the basic particles that make up the underlying structure of matter, and investigate related technologies

DBAFD4DF246D4EC2B0463D8D620C2CEB.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

4B8B8D5444F144E9A4726572E10ACB5A.description: Energy and Matter in Chemical Change
